conclusion: To determine the proportionality constant k in the Millikan oil-drop experiment, we need to analyze the forces acting on the oil droplets and their motion.
Droplet A falls with a uniform velocity v_A through a distance h_1 in time t.
The forces acting on A are gravitational force F_g = m_0 g and air resistance f_A = k m_0^{1/3} v_A.

premise: Since A moves with constant velocity, the net force is zero.

conclusion: Droplet B initially falls with the same velocity v_A as A.
When the voltage U is applied, B begins to move upwards with a uniform velocity v_B through a distance h_2 in time t.
The forces acting on B are gravitational force F_g = m_0 g, air resistance f_B = k m_0^{1/3} v_B, and electric force F_e = q E, where E = U / d and q is the charge on B.

premise: Since B moves with constant velocity upwards, the net force is zero.

conclusion: Substitute v_B into the force balance equation: m_0 g + k m_0^{1/3} (h_2 / t) = q U / d

premise: We have two expressions for v_A and v_B: v_A = m_0^{2/3} g / k and v_B = h_2 / t
conclusion: Since v_A = v_B (both droplets have the same initial velocity): m_0^{2/3} g / k = h_2 / t
Solving for k: k = m_0^{2/3} g t / h_2
